pull.title: lint: fix custom mypy cache dir setting
pull.body:
fixes #28183

The custom cache dir for `mypy` can only be set via an environment variable, setting the `MYPY_CACHE_DIR` variable in the program is not sufficient. This error was introduced while translating the shell script to python.

See also the mypy documentation: https://mypy.readthedocs.io/en/stable/config_file.html#confval-cache_dir

events.message: lint: fix custom mypy cache dir setting

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable

@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+os.environ["MYPY_CACHE_DIR"] = f"{os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', '')}/test/.mypy_cache"
comments.body:
This will write to `/test/` if a user is running this script:

```
# ./test/lint/lint-python.py 
Success: no issues found in 269 source files
# ls /test/.mypy_cache/
3.11  CACHEDIR.TAG

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
comments.body: If it is not needed, it may be better to remove it.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+os.environ["MYPY_CACHE_DIR"] = f"{os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', '')}/test/.mypy_cache"
comments.body: That was the previous behavior. There is even an explicit line for this in our `.gitignore`. What would you like to do instead? Move it into `/test/cache/`?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
comments.body: This was added as part of #18210 but I didn't see an explanation given there. I think it is better to specify a location explicitly since the default is using the current directory which may be leading to unexpected results if this script is called from different contexts. But if we don't care about something like this, it may be removed.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+os.environ["MYPY_CACHE_DIR"] = f"{os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', '')}/test/.mypy_cache"
comments.body:
No, I mean `/test/`, not `./test/`.

With `/test` being next to `/bin`, etc. I don't think `.gitignore` will work on the literal root of your filesystem. `.gitignore` should be limited to the folder it is located in.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+os.environ["MYPY_CACHE_DIR"] = f"{os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', '')}/test/.mypy_cache"
comments.body: I see, I simply misread. I changed this to get the base path relative to file as a fallback. We could also simply use `.` or fall back to not setting a `cache_dir` at all but this seemed the most robust option to me.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,11 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+base_dir = os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)))))
comments.body:
```suggestion
base_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
```

The two should be the same, no? Seems better to just use one way to get one thing, instead of two.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,11 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+base_dir = os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)))))
comments.body: If `BASE_ROOT_DIR` isn't used differently yes, I wasn't 100% sure about that. Done.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,11 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+base_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))
comments.body: nit: Maybe use https://docs.python.org/3.8/library/pathlib.html#pathlib.Path.resolve for new code? And `.parent` instead of `dirname`? And `operator/` over manual string formatting below?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,10 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+os.environ["MYPY_CACHE_DIR"] = f"{os.getenv('BASE_ROOT_DIR', '')}/test/.mypy_cache"
comments.body:
> I see, I simply misread. I changed this to get the base path relative to file as a fallback. We could also simply use `.` or fall back to not setting a `cache_dir` at all but this seemed the most robust option to me.

Wouldn't the default option result in placing the cache dir in the root, regardless of where the script is being run from?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -13,8 +13,11 @@
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+base_dir = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))))

@@ -9,14 +9,18 @@
 """
 
 import os
+from pathlib import Path
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
 from importlib.metadata import metadata, PackageNotFoundError
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+base_dir = Path(__file__).parent.parent.parent
+cache_dir = base_dir / "test" / ".mypy_cache"

@@ -9,14 +9,18 @@
 """
 
 import os
+from pathlib import Path
 import subprocess
 import sys
 
 from importlib.metadata import metadata, PackageNotFoundError
 
+# Customize mypy cache dir via environment variable
+base_dir = Path(__file__).parent.parent.parent
+cache_dir = base_dir / "test" / ".mypy_cache"
